awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Transformational Method to Extract Polychlorinated Biphenyls (PCBs) from Building Masonry
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase 1 project is solving the legacy polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) problem impacting our aging schools and infrastructure.  The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) estimates as many as 55,000 schools and 800,000 government and non-government buildings may have been constructed with PCB-laden paints, caulks, mastics and adhesives before the 1979 PCBs ban. Simply removing the PCB-laden source in hopes it will eliminate the hazard has proven futile as a growing body of data is revealing PCBs from weathered caulk can leach as deep as 6-inches into adjacent porous masonry (e.g., concrete, brick, and mortar). Currently, total demolition and select removal (i.e., partial demolition) are the only EPA-approved PCB removal options and both are quickly filling up the handful of landfills willing to take it. The proposed technical innovation will transform a dormant government patent that extracts PCBs in paint, into a non-destructive treatment method that penetrates and extracts PCBs absorbed in building masonry.  Such an innovation will have a direct and beneficial impact on the government agencies and school renovation commissions who cannot afford to demolish the old and rebuild new.  

This SBIR Phase 1 project proposes to demonstrate the feasibility of two proprietary solvent-paste formulations at extracting PCBs from different masonry types after the source (e.g., caulk) has been removed.  The solvent-paste is applied directly to the contaminated masonry surface and scraped off after a pre-determined treatment period.  Once applied, the lipophilic alcohol in the solvent-paste penetrates the masonry’s open pore spaces, and solubilizes the PCB molecules it encounters along the way. The process of desorbing the PCBs from the inorganic masonry particles and into the applied paste is aided – via capillary action – by the lipophilic alcohol drawing the hydrophobic PCBs toward the paste. Technical challenges include desorbing the stickier spectrum of hydrophobic Aroclors (e.g., 1248, 1254, 1260) added to paints, caulks and adhesives in seasonally cool (< 50°F), wet weather.  Since successful commercialization of an alternative PCB treatment technology requires approval from EPA in accordance with the PCB regulations (40 CFR 761), the performance of both solvent-pastes will be evaluated against the regulation’s stringent 1 ppm high occupancy cleanup criterion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes

This project's objective was to complete development of a solvent-paste that chemically extracts polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) from porous building masonry after the PCB sources (e.g., caulk, paint, adhesive) have been removed. The non-destructive treatment method was patented in 2012 to extract PCBs from paint (US 8163972 B2) and later reformulated to extract PCBs from porous masonry (US 17/043,913).  

Since remediating PCBs is a regulated activity, the project was performed under 40 CFR 761.60(j), the Toxic Substances Control Act (TSCA) self-implementing requirements for research and development. The project data quality objectives were developed in accordance with the Uniform Federal Policy for Quality Assurance Plans and adopted regulatory framework the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) established for the novel method following a successful project outcome: specifically, a TSCA risk-based cleanup in conformance with 40 CFR 761.61(c) and compliance with the PCBs ≤ 1 ppm self-implementing high occupancy cleanup criterion cited in 40 CFR 761.61(a)(4)(i)(A).  The project also adhered to EPA sample collection protocols and analytical methods for PCB sources and porous surfaces. Due to COVID travel restrictions, PCB Coordinators from the Connecticut Department of Energy & Environmental Protection (DEEP) visited the site on behalf of EPA.

The project tested both patented formulations on porous masonry, it corrected the PCBs ≤ 50 ppm success criteria the patent holders based their proof-of-concept research on, and it challenged certain claims made in the patents. The project also built on an inconclusive bench study EPA performed in 2012 that evaluated the novel method using PCB-spiked concrete prepared in the lab (EPA/600/R-11/156C). To avoid a similar outcome, this project was performed "in the wild" at a vacant elementary school in Hartford County Connecticut where PCB-1254 added to caulk has been leaching into the adjacent building masonry since its application around 1971. 

The project evaluated the efficacy of 8 solvent-paste formulations using different sorbents in both patented solvent systems. The project tested several equivalent (or better) sorbent alternatives to replace an uncommercialized sorbent the patent-pending masonry reformulation is based on.

The post-application confirmation data confirms every solvent-paste formulation tested dissolves and extracts PCBs sorbed in masonry (PCBs detected in the spent solvent-paste samples verify this). However, none of the formulations achieved the project's PCBs ≤ 1 ppm success criterion, even after multiple applications. Moreover, when comparing the masonry pre-characterization data alongside multiple rounds of post-application confirmation data, the spatially-mapped data suggests solvent separating from the applied pastes are also dissolving and dispersing pockets of concentrated PCBs deeper into the structure's most porous preferential pathway (e.g., mortar) rather than toward/into the applied paste, as desired. This unexpected observation appears to be enlarging the PCBs > 1 ppm contaminant profile in the mortar rather than reducing it, and should be evaluated further.

Intellectual Merit:

The project applied sound research techniques that moved the novel method out of the laboratory and into the real world. In doing so, this project was specifically oriented to the high-risk aspects of developing this transformative method for use on occupied masonry structures. The ultimate objective of the regulated activity was to achieve the TSCA regulation's PCBs ≤ 1 ppm cleanup level required throughout the treated masonry so EPA would approve this economically-viable alternative to current destructive remedial methods. We did not achieve that goal.

Broader/Commercial Impact:

While the project did not result in a commercial success, the PCB source (e.g., caulk, paint, etc.) and masonry (e.g., brick, mortar, horn grout) pre-characterization data the project team collected is advancing the industry's understanding of how legacy PCBs sorbed in porous surfaces behave "in the wild."  This became evident when the project team shared the caulk and masonry pre-characterization data with EPA, the Connecticut DEEP, and 31 subject matter experts interviewed during our participation in the NSF beat-the-odds boot camp.
